Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Arraignment and Detention Hearing as to Erica Melendez-Algarin held on 10/3/2008. Present were AUSA Dina Avila and Francisco Dolz. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. PONG entered as to all applicable counts of the Indictment. The Government was granted 5 days to provide discovery. Case was referred to Judge Gelpi for trial setting. Defense counsel requested bail as defendant had ties in the community. The Government objected and requested detention without bail, until trial. The Court set bail in the amount of $10,000.00, which $1,000.00 shall be secured by cash or real estate property, standard conditions of release recommended by the Pre Trial report. Defendant shall not reside or visit Jesus T. Pineiro Public Housing Project. Defendant shall not have contact with any potential witnesses on this case, unless accompanied by counsel. Defendant was placed on Curfew restricted to her residence daily from 6:00 PM to 6:00 AM and shall seek employment or education. (Court Reporter FTR.) Discovery was provided.(Court Interpreter Hilda Gutierrez, US P.O Wallace Bustelo)Hearing set for 11:00.Hearing held at 11:12.Hearing ended at 11:20. (er) (Entered: 10/07/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:DeNovo Hearing as to Alice Martinez-Vila held on 10/10/2008. Testimony of Nilda I. Marquez is heard on behalf of the government. Exhibit 2 is admitted. Government's proffer heard and requests detention. Defense counsel argues that conditions of release remain in effect. Court further discusses the case with the USPO. Court sets bail at $20,000 ($15,000 secured and $5,000 unsecured). Home detention with EMD, no curfew, defendant must reside with her mother who has been approved as her third party custodian, urinalysis, remain or seek employment, participate in an educational program and receive mental treatment. Cannot reside or visit the Jesus T. Pineiro Public Housing Project. When the defendant is studying or working, the PTS Officer is to approve her schedule. (Court Reporter Yvette Richardson.)(Court Interpreter Tom Kavelin.)Hearing set for 2:00 p.m. Hearing held at 3:38 p.m. Hearing ended at 4:25 p.m. (sr) Present: AUSA Dina Avila, defense counsel Vladimir Mihailovich, defendant assisted by Court Interpreter Tom Kavelin. USPO Evelyn Jimenez. Interpreter Juan Llagostera, for the government. (Entered: 10/10/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:DeNovo Bail Hearing as to Erica Melendez-Algarin held on 10/10/2008. Testimony of Task Force agent Nilda I. Marques heard on behalf of the government. Arguments by both parties heard. Government's exhibit 3 was admitted into evidence. The Court ordered that defendant conditions of release shall be modified as follows: $11,000 of which $1,000 cash or secured (already posted with the Court) and $10,000 with the signature of a solvent surety. Maintain or seek employment, maintain and /or commence and an education program, curfew restricted to her residence daily from 6:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. Defendant shall not reside or visit the Jesus T. Pinero Public Housing Project. Defendant shall not have contact with any potential witnesses in this case unless accompanied by counsel. All other conditions of release are on effect. Defendant is granted until 10/17/08 to provide a solvent suretor. (Court Reporter Yvette Richardson.)(Court Interpreter Tom Kavelin.)Hearing set for 02:00.Hearing held at 04:24.Hearing ended at 05:00. (cr) (Entered: 10/10/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Arraignment and Bail Hearing as to Wendel Martoral-Ayuso (21) held on 10/22/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment. Plea of not guilty is entered as to Counts 1-4, 6. Case is referred to Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi for trial setting. The government requested detention without bail. Defense counsel argued in favor of setting  conditions of release. Bail is set at $10,000 ($5,000 secured by cash or property and $5,000 unsecured), with drug treatment, home detention, E/M, 3rd party custodian, plus standard conditions of release. Defendant's grandmother 1s to be interviewed by PTS as a potential 3rd party custodian. Defendant shall not reside at or visit the Jesus T. Pinero Public Housing Project. Defendant shall not be released until bond is posted, 3rd party custodian is approved, and E/M arrangements have been made. (AUSA Sean Torriente. CJA Atty Juan M. Rodriguez-Lopez. PO Patricia Encarnacion. CR FTR. CI Janis Palma.)(Hearing set for 2:30, held at 3:32, ended at 3:38.) (jm) (Entered: 10/23/2008)

Tortora, 922 F. 2d 880, 888 (1st Cir. 1990). More so, this defendant has not rebutted the statutory presumptions of danger to the community and risk of flight. The government, by way of the evidence presented at the de novo hearing, has further met the appropriate evidentiary burden of persuasion. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/5/08. Lopez: Present were AUSA Dina Avila, Rachel Brill and PTO Evelyn Jimenez.Arraignment and Bail Hearing as to Hector Rivera-Febres (6) Count 1,2,3,4,5,6 held on 12/8/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment and enters a PONG as to all counts. The case is referred to Judge Gelpi for trial setting. As to bail, defense counsel states that defendant is presently serving sentence in Federal Court to a prior case and has nothing to offer. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Appearing for the Government, Mariana Bauza and for defendant, Elfrick Mendez- Morales. Defendant is present in Court and is (U/C).Arraignment and Bail Hearing as to Jeffrey Carrasquillo-Ocasio (39) Count 1,2,3,4,6 held on 12/8/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and enters a PONG as to all counts. The case is referred to Judge Gelpi for trial setting. As to bail, defense counsel states that defendant has prior criminal record and he was brought from the State of New York for these charges and until these charges are clear, bail cannot be requested. Counsel for the Government is heard as to bail and requests that defendant be detain. The Court states that defendant has an extensive record of previous encounters with the law and taking into account the statements made by counsel, the government and the pretrial report, finds that defendant is a risk of flight and danger to the community and orders that defendant be detain pending trial. (Court Reporter FTR.)(Court Interpreter Edna Brayfield.)Hearing set for 02:00.Hearing held at 02:13.Hearing ended at 02:18. (mn) (Entered: 12/11/2008)

ORDER re: 866 Motion to Inspect as to Jesus M. Diaz-Correa: Noted. The court finds that the administrative records submitted by the government must be provided to the defense pursuant to Giglio and Kyles. The court accordingly orders that the same be immediately provided to defendants' counsel via hard copy, e-mail or fax. This material shall only be reviewed by counsel and defendants for trial purposes and shall not be disclosed to third parties, except upon prior court order. Failure to comply with this order shall result in severe sanctions, including contempt of court. This ruling however, does not automatically entitle cross-examination as to each item contained in the administrative files. At trial the defense will announce outside of the jury's presence its intent to rely on such material for impeachment or any other purpose. The government, in turn, may object under Rules 401, 403, or any other applicable Rule of Evidence. The Government is allowed until September 10, 2009 to submit any outstanding administrative files. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 9/9/09. (CSL) (Entered: 09/09/2009)

ORDER denying 1750 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Carmen Santos- Rivera (26). Although the court finds defendant's argument persuasive. In this case, the court, in the exercise of its discretion, chooses not to reduce the sentence due to other sentencing considerations. The sentence of 70 months, which the result of a well- negotiated plea agreement (docket 746), limited defendant's criminal exposure for violations of 21 USC secs 841, 846 and 860. Defendant admitted in her plea agreement at and the change of plea hearing that she participated as a seller and facilitator in a conspiracy to distribute crack, cocaine, heroin, marijuana, percocet and Xanax. For purposes of the plea agreement, the parties stipulated a crack amount that would yield a sentence of 70 months, and disregarded any other drugs. In other words, this is not a plea where defendant only dealt a minor crack amount. Rather, it is a case where crack was chosen by the parties (vis a vis heroin, cocaine, etc) for purposes of a particular sentence, which the court adopted. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/22/11. (cr) (Entered: 11/22/2011)
ORDER granting and approved as stipulated 1749 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Hector Rivera-Febres (6). Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/22/11. (cr) (Entered: 11/22/2011)

ORDER denying 1748 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Erica Melendez- Algarin (28). Although the Court finds defendant's argument persuasive. in this case, the court, in the exercise of its discretion, chooses not to reduce the sentence due to other sentencing considerations. The sentence of 66 months, which the result of a well- negotiated plea agreement (docket 817), limited defendant's criminal exposure for violations of 21 USC secs 841, 846 and 860. Defendant admitted in her plea agreement at and the change of plea hearing that she participated as a seller and facilitator in a conspiracy to distribute crack, cocaine, marijuana, percocet and Xanax. For purposes of the plea agreement, the parties stipulated a crack amount that would yield a sentence of 70 months, and disregarded any other drugs. In other words, this is not a plea where defendant only dealt a minor crack amount. Rather, it is a case where crack was chosen by the parties (vis a vis heroin, cocaine, etc) for purposes of a particular sentence, which the court adopted. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 11/22/11. (cr) (Entered: 11/22/2011)

ORDER denying 1765 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Maria del Carmen Gautier-Rodriguez (22). The Court has considered defendant's argument, which is plausible. However, the Court, in the exercise of its discretion shall not reduce the sentence originally imposed, which was the result of a plea agreement which drastically limited her sentencing exposure. This was not a case involving mere crack, but rather a large drug conspiracy where other drugs were involved, and defendant could have faced a 10 year mandatory minimum. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/5/11. (cr) (Entered: 12/05/2011)

ORDER denying 1794 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Victor Corsino- Garcia (23). The Court in the exercise of its discretion will not reduce the sentence imposed. Defendant participated in a large drug conspiracy as a seller, facilitator as well as a cocaine-crack cook, processor and packager (see statement of facts in plea agreement - dkt 738 at p 15). He had the benefit of a plea agreement (which the court followed) wherein his exposure was limited to a definite crack amount, for a specific sentence result. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/28/11. (cr) (Entered: 12/28/2011)

ORDER denying 1795 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Luis Estrada- Vazquez (31). The Court, in the exercise of its discretion will not reduce the sentence imposed. Defendant was part of a large multi-drug conspiracy, wherein he acted as seller and facilitator. The plea agreement (which the court followed) recommended a specific sentence and to achieve the same, stipulated a reduced crack quantity. This scenario is different to that where a defendant particpates in a small drug transaction involving the same amount of crack stipulated in this case. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 12/28/11. (cr) (Entered: 12/28/2011)

ORDER denying 1841 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Jonathan Suarez- Ramirez (34). The Court notes that this defendant entered a plea agreement as to specific and reduced drug amount so as to produce the sentence of 65 months -- followed by the court. The Court further notes that this was a large scale conspiracy and the indictment included additional counts which were dismissed. The Court, in the exercise of its discretion will not reduce the sentence (even 6 months). The sentence  received was fair within the circumstances, and as the court noted at sentencing, sufficient but not greater than necessary as per 18 U.S.C. Sec. 3553(a); it continues as such. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 3/12/12. (cr) (Entered: 03/12/2012)

ORDER denying 1849 Motion to Reduce Sentence re Crack Cocaine Offense - 18:3582 as to Carlos Jimenez-Rosado (33). The jury's verdict reveals that defendant was not only convicted for crack (in excess of 50 grams), but also for cocaine (5 kilos or more) (see docket 1033). The Court, in the excercise of its discretion, and pursuant to a variance, sentenced defendant to 65 months (docket 1524). The Court, at the time took into consideration defendant's role in this large sale conspiracy, as well as his specific participation, and all other Section 3553(a) factors. At this time, the Court will not reduce the sentence because it involves cocaine as well. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 3/14/12. (cr) (Entered: 03/14/2012)

ORDER: Denying 1883 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Ismael Heredia- Ortiz (1). Defendant Heredia was the owner, leader and supervisor of the drug point in this large scale multi-drug conspiracy, as well as possessed firearms in furtherance thereof. The court, in the exercise of its discretion, finds that the original sentence well within the advisory sentencing guidelines, as well as below the maximum possible sentence 1s one that is sufficient, but not greater than necessary under 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a). The fact that defendant accepted responsibility for crack for sentencing purposes does not do away with his admission in the statement of facts (Docket No. 728) that he was also involved with cocaine and other drugs as part of the overarching conspiracy. More so, the court considered his arson conviction in 07-54 (DRD) as relevant conduct, thus crediting time served in said case. To reduce defendants sentence of 192 months (minus a 22 month credit for 07-54 (DRD)) at this time would, in the courts opinion run contrary to the mandate of Section 3553(a), particularly resulting in the court ignoring the nature and circumstances of the offense, as well as the need to deter such conduct. Finally, the court notes that such reduction would be inequitable as to other less culpable co-defendants. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/17/2012. (TC) (Entered: 04/17/2012)

ORDER: Denying 1737 Motion to Reduce Sentence re Crack Cocaine Offense - 18:3582 as to Ismael Heredia-Ortiz (1). See ruling at Docket No. 1884.Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/17/2012. (TC) (Entered: 04/17/2012)

ORDER: Denying 1882 Subsequent Motion re: Crack Cocaine as to Josean Domenech- Robles (10). Defendant Domenech was an enforcer and seller of the drug points in this large scale multi-drug conspiracy, as well as possessed a firearm in furtherance thereof. The court, in the exercise of its discretion, finds that the original sentence well within the advisory sentencing guidelines, as well as below the maximum possible sentence is one that is sufficient, but not greater than necessary under 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a). The fact that defendant accepted responsibility for crack for sentencing purposes does not do  away with his admission in the statement of facts (Docket No. 1162) that he was also involved with cocaine and other drugs as part of the overarching conspiracy. More so, the court considered his arson conviction in 07-54 (DRD) as relevant conduct, thus crediting time served in said case. To reduce defendants sentence of 84 months (minus a 22 month credit for 07-54 (DRD)) at this time would, in the courts opinion run contrary to the mandate of Section 3553(a), particularly resulting in the court ignoring the nature and circumstances of the offense, as well as the need to deter such conduct. Finally, the court notes that such reduction would be inequitable as to other less culpable co- defendants. Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 4/17/2012. (TC) (Entered: 04/17/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi:Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Luis Estrada- Vazquez (31) held on 12/7/2015, Present were AUSA Seth Erbe and AFPD Eleonora Marranzini. Defendant was present U/C and assisted by the court interpreter. Defendant did not challenged the allegations. Defense counsel arguments were heard as to the need of contiuous addiction treatment for the defendant; requested time served. The Government requested a revocation within the guideline range. The Court did not revoke supervised release at this time, instead defendant shall be provided inpatient treatment. Defense counsel requested self surrender after the holidays, request was denied. The US Probation Office shall make arrangements as to the facility where defendant will start treatment. BOP and USM shall release defendant to the US Probation Office on 12/08/2015 to start immediate inpatient treatment. Final Hearing Revocation of Supervised Release set for 3/7/2016 at 09:00 AM in Old San Juan Courtroom before Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi. ORDER denying 2270 Motion for Bond as to Luis Estrada- Vazquez (31). Upon consultation with USPO Guillermo Arbona, the request for conditions of release at this time is denied. The USPO originally recommended the pre-trial detention of defendant Estrada- Vazquez for multiple reasons including the nature of the offense, history of prior arrests, substance abuse history and violent behavior. Defendant Estrada- Vazquez was denied pre-trial release. Defendant Estrada- Vazquez has been provided with multiple opportunities while on supervised release and probable cause was already found for the supervised release violations informed in Docket No. 2264. As such, there are no grounds for conditions of release at this stage. Defendant Estrada- Vazquez will remain detained until the full revocation hearing is held. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 10/24/2016. (cvr) (Entered: 10/24/2016)

COPY OF JUDGMENT of USCA (certified copy) as to Jeffrey Carrasquillo-Ocasio (39); Petitioner Jeffrey Carrasquillo-Ocasio has filed papers that we construe as an application seeking permission from this court to present, by means of a second or successive petition for habeas corpus, a claim under Johnson v. United States. Petitioner's convictions and sentence did not stem from any statute or guideline provision called into question by Johnson. Accordingly, petitioner cannot satisfy either of the gatekeeping provisions set out at §2255(h). The application is DENIED. Th[is]... denial of an authorization... to file a second or successive application shall not be appealable and shall not be the subject of a petition for rehearing or for a writ of certiorari. (xi) (Entered: 02/24/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Josean Domenech-Robles (10) held on 2/17/2021 via VTC. Present was AFPD Eleonora Marranzini. Defendant was present under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his  right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via VTC. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motions filed at Docket Nos. 2447 & 2514 and as to his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether the supervised release conditions had been violated. Upon the defendant's request, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by the FPD's Office. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. No. 116-182, 134 Stat. 894 (Oct. 21, 2020) and Rule 5(f) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the United States is reminded of its obligation to disclose in a timely manner all exculpatory evidence to the defendant(s], that is, all evidence that is favorable to the defendant[s] or tends to cast doubt on the United States case, as required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963) and its progeny. Failure to comply with this order may result in consequences, including, but not limited to, the reversal of any conviction, the exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges, contempt proceedings, disciplinary action, and/or sanctions by the Court. Preliminary Revocation Hearing set for 3/3/2021 at 1:30 PM in VTC Bridge GLS before Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez- Soler. As to detention, defense counsel argued in favor of conditions of release. After hearing the defense, the Court ordered the USPO to file a motion within 3 days expressing their position as to release. (Court Reporter DCR/ZoomGov Recording.) Hearing held at 01:57. Hearing ended at 02:03. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (rom) (Entered: 02/18/2021)
ORDER APPOINTING FEDERAL PUBLIC DEFENDER as to Josean Domenech- Robles (10). Signed by Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler on 2/17/2021.(rom) (Entered: 02/18/2021)

ORDER: Noting 2534 Motion in Compliance with Court Order 2532 re: revocation of supervised release as to Josean Domenech-Robles (10). Signed by Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi on 2/22/2021. (MES) (Entered: 02/22/2021)

ORDER as to Josean Domenech-Robles (10) . At the Initial Appearance, counsel for Defendant requested conditions of release. The request is denied. Defendant has not met his burden under Rule 32.1(a)(6) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, and the Court finds that, given the violent nature of the allegations asserted by the USPO at Docket No. 2447 and that Defendant's conditions of supervised release have been previously revoked due to conduct of similar nature and weapons violations (Docket No. 2297), Defendant poses a risk of flight and a danger to the community. Defendant will remain detained pending revocation proceedings. Signed by Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler on February 22, 2021. (Lopez-Soler, Giselle) (Entered: 02/22/2021)

Miunute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Josean Domenech-Robles (10) held on 3/3/2021 via VTC. Present were SAUSA Yanira Colon, AFPD Lauren Rosen and USPO Camille Machado. The defendant was present under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed by way of VTC. Counsel for the defendant informed that they are waiving the preliminary hearing. The Court made a finding of probable cause as to the allegations contained in the motions filed at Docket No. 2447 & 2514 . Case is referred to Judge Gustavo A. Gelpi for setting of a final revocation hearing. As to detention, defense counsel argued in favor of conditions of release. The Government moved for detention. After hearing the parties, the Court ordered detained without bail pending the final revocation hearing. (Court Reporter DCR/ZoomGov Recording.) Hearing set for 01:30. Hearing held at 01:36. Hearing ended at 01:44. Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. (rom) (Entered: 03/04/2021)
